Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Conditioning Techniques for Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Conducted in a tertiary care hospital, this randomised controlled trial included adult patients at risk of IR injury during surgical procedures.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were allocated to receive either ischemic preconditioning (IPC) or remote ischemic preconditioning (RIPC) as the intervention, or standard care as the control.

Objective.evidence: The study aimed to evaluate the impact of conditioning techniques on reducing IR injury.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in biomarkers indicative of organ damage, assessed over a 72-hour period post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 assigned to each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, following an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant reduction in biomarkers of organ damage (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were minimal, with mild side effects reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.

Funding.evidence: The trial was supported by institutional grants, ensuring no conflict of interest.
